title: Sooky players need disciplinary action.
body:
Thanks to Riot 2.0 and their misguided crusade for rainbows and friendship on the internet, the vast majority of players in this community are extremely happy to forgo teamwork on the grounds of "toxicity".

Everyone cries about the nasty words people see in their games, but no one remembers that without teamwork the game is over.

Due to the mollycoddling from Riot 2.0, players cannot take criticism or advice without crying for reports and toxic.
Innocent advice is always met with childlike reactions that are more detrimental to teamwork, than "toxic" behavior ever could be.

"You should probably ward if you're that overextended"
"Could you please follow your lane or push"
"Please stop fighting him"

There goes your communication, and a large advantage with it.

If a player is pissed off  they died and begin to act rudely towards their team, they get punished.
If a player is pissed off they died and completely shut off their team, they get away without a second thought, even though it is just harmful to the entire team.

Muting your team unnecessarily negatively impacts four other people. Saying some rude words impacts one. 

Why is the lesser crime punished? There has to be some sort of punishment for people who are more than happy to throw games because they are in a bad mood.

replies.body:
People usually don't cry foul when someone gives them constructive criticism. It's when everything surrounding the constructive criticism indicates it might be something else that a problem usually arises. 

For example, I can't explain how many times I've seen one of the following precede legitimate criticism:

_"gg"_ 
_"..."_
_"sigh"_ 
_"open mid"_
_"ff20"_
_"I'm done"_

Not only does the person who just made a mistake probably feel bad (maybe they even know what they did wrong) but the last thing they want is someone on their back. I'm not suggesting everyone is incapable of giving constructive criticism or that everyone is incapable of taking it but some consideration is definitely required when delivering it since you never know who you're dealing with and what's going on through their head.

Hey man

I just want to clarify, the quotes you posted are not reportable behavior and wont trigger any punishment by themselves.
Now on to the main post:

+ Concepts such as warding, over-extending and others, can be confusing for newer or more inexperienced players.

 To be honest, no one is going to learn the complexities of how and when to ward effectively, during a single game. These skills often take multiple games to practice and understand.

 If you remind someone to ward, and they ignore it or act negatively to your advice, then it's best just to forget about it and ward their lane yourself.

+ Going over mistakes is something traditionally done in post-match analysis sessions, for pro League of Legends and other sports. That's because you want to reduce the amount of negativity during the match, so that it has the smallest impact possible on the game.

 The player who died to a gank knows he's messing up, he might not understand why, but he already knows there's something wrong. Some people wont appreciate quick tips, when they are already stressed out and worried about performing badly.

+ If you really want to help players improve, try adding them after a game. The aim when doing something like this should be to respectfully point out **what went wrong**, **why it went wrong** and **how it can be prevented** next time.

 If the player doesn't want your advice then don't force it on them, that's their choice.

I hope this helps.

I am not asking what is reportable and what is not. I am asking why is there no punishment or discouragement for exaggerated reactions to friendly chat.
I am also fully aware asking a team mate to report you isn't against the rules, and you can't be punished for it. **Thats entirely my point.**

Childish players will see it as aggressive behavior and instantly mute you, even though your advice was nice in nature.

This instantly puts your team at a disadvantage, because now you cannot communicate as effectively as the enemy team.

I couldn't give a fuck if other players improve or not. I don't care if they take the advice or not. 

I care when they see it as something worth muting over and potentially throw the entire game because they put their fingers in their ears and scream "lalala not listening."

Muting your team is incredibly detrimental to the game, and affects more than just a single player, so it needs to be used accordingly, not when you're in a bad mood.

I'm sorry for misunderstanding initially, I think this is more what you were looking for:

**Every player holds the right to mute whoever he/she sees fit for whatever reason.** 

If you don't want players to mute the team, then don't give them advice. Especially since you _"don't care if they take the advice or not."_, this might not be the best attitude to have when giving advice in-game.

Muting the team or any players for any reason, is not, and will not be reportable in League.
Would you agree that unnecessary muting is detrimental to teamwork?

"Detrimental" may be an exaggeration. The introduction of the [smart ping system](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752974-Smart-Ping) a while back made communication without chat far more viable.

_It is possible that muting your team has negative effects on teamwork? _

Almost certainly, but it's not worth removing or punishing the use of this feature at the expense of players having to endure harassment in chat.

So you agree that players who **MISUSE** the mute feature are intentionally decreasing their chances of the team winning?




Why is that any different than going AFK or walking at the enemy team.

Players who pick Nunu (lowest winrate ATM) are also _statistically_ decreasing their team's chances of winning. However much like muting this is not reportable, because its far more important for us to protect each player's right to play what they want, than it is for us to protect team winrates. This protects the *player experience*.

Muting is similar to this. **Riot** is happy to protect the player experience at the expense of 1-2% winrate for the team.

AFK and feeding strongly negatively impacts the player experience and this is why these are considered serious offenses and are reportable. AFKing will stop harassment for a player, but it's not the best option since winrates can be affected by [up to 35%](http://www.manaless.com/2015/05/afk-4v5-games-analysis-using-kaplan.html) and it undoubtably ruins the game for everyone else involved. Muting may to this to a very minor extent but the trade off is well worth it.

That being said, if you think you have a better idea or reform, I'm sure the player behavior team world love to hear it. You can try and get in touch with **Riot Lyte** [here](https://twitter.com/riotlyte?lang=en) and [here](https://ask.fm/RiotLyte). 

Remember to be patient and respectful, Rioters have a lot on their plate already ;)
